name: AI Workflow Implementation Process
description: A phased approach to identifying, refining, building, and rolling out AI workflow solutions in organizations
components: Discovery Phase - Comprehensive workflow identification and assessment
Refinement Phase - Building provisional business case and minimum viable solution plan
Build and Pilot Phase - Create and test MVP/prototype with minimum viable solution
Rollout and Training Phase - Implementation, change management, and team training
evidence_quote: The next phase I'm calling refinement, which is basically once we say, okay, we've got this list and we've got some that have bubbled to the top, now we have to actually dig in... Then we will actually build and pilot the MVP or the prototype... then the rollout and the training and the implementation
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: Refinement Phase Dual-Component Model
description: A two-part model for validating workflow redesign viability before full investment
components: Provisional Business Case - Investment justification for the workflow
Minimum Viable Solution - Test and prototype to validate AI output capability
evidence_quote: there's two components to that. There's what is the provisional kind of business case to invest behind this workflow? And what is the minimum viable solution to test and prototype whether AI can actually get to the output that the organization or division needs
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: Workflow Deep-Dive Assessment Framework
description: A structured approach to understanding current workflow mechanics before AI redesign
components: Current Process Mapping - What are they actually doing
Output Definition - What's the output
Quality Standards - What are the quality bars and accuracy requirements
Technical Environment - What platforms and tools do they have access to
Skill Requirements - What level of technical skill set is needed
evidence_quote: We have to sit down with the person who's doing the RFP process and say, what are they actually doing? What's the output? What are the quality bars that they have? Right. Like, let's talk about what level of accuracy is required... What kind of platforms and tools do they have access to? And therefore, can we build the solution on that, or do we have to go get something else? What's the level of technical, kind of, you know, skill set or requirement that's needed
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: Minimum Viable Prototyping Approach
description: A strategy to prototype AI solutions cheaply before building custom applications
components: Use Off-the-Shelf Tools - Leverage existing AI platforms
Custom GPTs for Prototyping - Even for workflows needing custom applications
Low/No-Code Tool Integration - Combine tools without heavy development
Validate Before Building - Prove concept before custom development
evidence_quote: you want to prototype this and the cheapest kind of minimum viable solution that you can. And the benefit of AI is you can do a lot of that using tools that are off the shelf. Even if we think we've found a workflow that needs a custom built application, we would still highly recommend the organization prototype using if they have GPT, custom GPTs, maybe some integrations with other low or no code tools
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: Pre-Refinement Decision Framework
description: Decision logic to determine proper scoping and pricing before building AI workflow solutions
components: If jumping straight to building - Stop and do refinement work first
Understand requirements before pricing - Need refinement to price and staff accurately
Client needs cost data to decide - Refinement provides necessary investment information
evidence_quote: I think we're seeing that it's the step that most organizations are missing, right? They're like, we want to redesign our RFP process, so let's jump right to building the AI tool. And it's like, okay, first we just have to do some work... we need to do that to be able to price it and staff it. And they need that output to know whether they should invest at the cost needed to get the output required
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: 30-Day Pilot Evaluation Framework
description: A structured approach to evaluate pilot success and determine next steps
components: Success Evaluation - Did this work or did this not
Training Documentation - Information team needs to maintain the solution
Change Management Plan - For larger organizations to ensure proper workflow adoption
evidence_quote: if we run the 30 day pilot then we have to actually say okay, did this work or did this not? And if it did, here's the training, here's the information that the team needs to maintain the thing that we've built for them or here's, you know, if it's a much larger organization, the change management that has to be done to get everyone actually doing the workflow up properly
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: Parallel Work Stream Engagement Model
description: A model for running transformation assessment and workflow discovery simultaneously as separate but coordinated deliverables
components: Deep Dive/Transformation Plan - Separate deliverable with existing scope
Workflow Discovery and Refinement - Parallel separate deliverable
Integrated Sales Approach - Presented as coordinated package to client
Separate Scoping - Each maintains distinct scope and pricing
evidence_quote: you're. Well, let's talk about what's in it and then we can, you can see the realities of that. There would be two parallel work streams, basically... the scope of the transformation plan or the deep dive stays what it is today... You wouldn't. We wouldn't say, Bobby, as part of the. I mean you can say as part of that like phase of work, but they would be separate
source_transcript: transcripts_taylor_temp/Refining AI Workflows and Strategies for Effective Implementation 2025-08-12 11_09 transcript.json

name: AI Maturity Deep Dive Process
description: A phased consulting methodology for assessing client AI readiness and delivering recommendations
components: Phase 1a: Employee survey (all employees within scope)
Phase 1b: Stakeholder interviews (leadership and selected employees)
Phase 1c: Data analysis and insights synthesis
Deliverable 1: Initial insights readout (strengths, weaknesses, evidence-based pain points)
Deliverable 2: Recommendations roadmap (custom projects, activities, and sequencing for ROI)
evidence_quote: from a process perspective, what that looks like is we...start off by doing our survey to all employees, whatever that scope to be. And then we do a bunch of interviews that go across leadership and...employees as well...So once we do all of that assessment work, we then need to share it with the client. So we do that in two blocks...the first one is...the, like, initial insights readout...the next deck is our plan or set of recommendations, and that's a roadmap of projects and activities and sequenc that they should take to get ROI from AI
